titleStmt.title: Walters Ms. W.199, Gossouin of Metz, Image du Monde
Table of chapter headings
Prologues

Image du Monde

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript, which is dated in a colophon to 1489, is one of the three known fifteenth-century copies of a rare vernacular cosmography originally composed in verse under the title "Image du Monde" (The Mirror of the World) in Lorraine dialect ca. 1245-46. The manuscript provides descriptions of the seven liberal arts along with astronomical theories, especially about the earth, the creatures that inhabit it, and its movements within the universe. Each one of the liberal arts is illustrated with a small miniature in grisaille, and extraordinary geometric astronomical diagrams recur throughout the book. The importance of W.199 is both textual and pictorial. Illuminated by followers of Willem Vrelant, active in Bruges 1454-1481, the manuscript reveals affinity of format and content with a 1464 copy of the Mirror of the World made in Bruges (London, British Library, Royal 19 A.IX).

msContents.textLang: The primary language in this manuscript is French. The secondary language of this manuscript is Latin.

msItem.title: Image du Monde
msItem.rubric: Chi commenche la table des Rubrices de ce present volume appelle le miroir du monde.
msItem.note: Text in French: diagrams inscribed in French and Latin

msItem.title: Table of chapter headings
msItem.rubric: Chi commenche la table des Rubrices de ce present volume appelle le miroir du monde. et primes
msItem.incipit: Prologue declarant a qui ce volume appartient

msItem.title: Prologues
msItem.note: Fol. 6r-v: Prologues of the translator: the first prologue declares that the book is a French translation entitled "ymage du monde" from the Latin text commissioned in 1245 by John, duke of Berry and Auvergne; fol. 6v explains that the organization of the text was accomplished in Bruges in 1464 ("MCCCC.lxiiii" with the second and last "C" erased, giving as apparent date "MCC.lxiiii")

msItem.title: Creation, seven liberal arts, and firmament
msItem.incipit: Chi commence le liure appelle le miroir du monde.

msItem.title: On partition of the earth
msItem.rubric: Fol. 46v: Chi commenche la seconde partie de che present liure Et declaire comment la terre est devisee et quelle part elle poeut estre habitee.
msItem.incipit: Puis que la terre est tant petite

msItem.title: Natural phenomena
msItem.rubric: Fol. 93r: Chi fine la seconde partie de che present liure. Et chi commenche la tierche partie de che present volume qui chy apres sinsieult.
msItem.incipit: En ceste tierche et derreniere partie

msItem.title: Epilogue
msItem.note: The epilogue explains that the volume was commissioned by John, duke of Berry and Auvergne in 1245; reference to "Iehan clerc librarien" in Bruges, credited with organizing this edition in 1444 (probably scribal error for date 1464 written on fol. 6v); prayers for physical and spiritual benefits for the readers or auditors

support.p: Well-selected and prepared heavy parchment, with stained and grimed margins

supportDesc.foliation: Paper flyleaves; crimson silk used as pastedown and glued to the first and last flyleaves of the manuscript

collation.p: Quires 1-16: 8 (fols. 3-130); Quire 17: 4 (fols. 131-134) Signatures in arabic numerals appear occasionally on lower right of page; in paler brown ink than that of text; see fols. 35r-38r for a complete, although rare, set Catchwords frequently extant beginning on fol. 26v; appearing on page high at center or just right of center; in paler brown ink than that of text Original foliation at head-edge of page; in roman numerals beginning after calendar on fol. 6r of modern penciled foliation

decoDesc.decoNote: One blue (2 lines) and one red initial (3 lines) mark the beginning of each prologue
Sixteen miniatures (ranging from 6-17 lines) in quadrangular frames mark the divisions of the text
Diagrams (6-10 lines) throughout; red or blue initials (3-6 lines) mark the major divisions of the text
One full-page miniature; five diagrams (6-18 lines); red or blue initials (3-4 lines) mark the major divisions of the text

One full-page illumination; 11 smaller figural miniatures in grisaille; 27 polychrome scientific diagrams; blue or red initials (2-6 lines) mark the major and minor divisions of the text; rubrics in red, text in dark brown ink

decoNote.title: Cleric teaching four clerics
God with armillary sphere
God the Father with compass
Creation of Eve
Cleric teaching four clerics
Discussion between clerics
King addressing three clerics
Cleric counting
Cleric seated at table set with compass, dividers, and geometric shapes
Cleric playing bells
Cleric with sextant, addressing four clerics
The earth and the spheres of the four elements
decoNote.note: Comment la terre se tient droit au fin milieu du monde

decoNote.title: Roundness of the earth: men walking around circumference
decoNote.note: Comment la terre se tient droit au fin milieu du monde

decoNote.title: Roundness of the earth: distance traveled by stones cast to the center of the earth
decoNote.note: Comment la terre se tient droit su fin milieu du monde

decoNote.title: Roundness of the earth: distance traveled by stones cast to the center of the earth
decoNote.note: Comment la terre se tient droit au fin milieu du monde

decoNote.title: Roundness of the earth: distance traveled by stones cast to the center of the earth
decoNote.note: Quelle la reondesse de la terre est

decoNote.title: Roundess of the earth created by God
decoNote.note: Pour quoy dieu fist le monde reond

decoNote.title: Three diagrams of the division of the earth
decoNote.note: Chi commence la seconde partie de che present liure et declaire comment la terre est devisee et quelle part elle poeut estre habitee

note.p: Corners of top panel inscribed: "la pomme fendue en quatre quartie[r]s"; at the center of the folio, the diagram at the right reads: "la droite ligne de midi"

decoNote.title: Division of the earth
decoNote.note: Chi commence la seconde partie de che present liure et declaire comment la terre est devisee et quelle part elle poeut estre habitee

note.p: Top left diagram inscribed top center clockwise: "paradis / terrestre / terre / Midis / Occident / Mars / Septentrion"; the diagram below has the corners above inscribed: "Ori / ant," and the corners below: "Occi / dant"

decoNote.title: Diagrams of the division of the earth
decoNote.note: Apres soit chascune partie tournee vers son nom en terre

note.p: The diagram at the top left has inscriptions from center top clockwise: "Orians / Mars / Occidant"; the diagram below has a blue top half of the earth labeled: "Ayse le grant" at the center and "Oriant" below at the left; the lower half of the earth is divided into red and pink quadrants, respectively labeled: "Septentr[i]on" and "Midi"

decoNote.title: Diagram of the division of the earth

note.p: The top half of the diagram is inscribed: "Oriant / Ayse la grant / Midi"; pink and red quadrants below are respectively inscribed: "Europe / Anfrique"

decoNote.title: Spheres of the planets
decoNote.note: Car il auroit plustost fait son cours

note.p: From the innermost band out, the concentric circles are inscribed: "terre / yane / airs / feus / pur air / planetes"

decoNote.title: Spheres of the planets
decoNote.note: Du tour du firmament et des etoilles

note.p: Circles inscribed from the innermost out: "Terra / Mercurius / Venus / Sol / Mars / Jupiter / Saturnus"

decoNote.title: Spheres of the planets
decoNote.note: Du tour du firmament et des estoilles

note.p: Inscribed from the innermost circle out: "Terra / Mars / Luna / Mercurius / Jupiter / Venus / Sol / Saturnus"

decoNote.title: The sun, the moon, and the shadow of the earth
decoNote.note: Chi declaire comment le iour et la nuit viennent

note.p: Basic components are a gold sun at top left labeled "Sol", a white area, a small earth labeled "Terra", and a black band of cast shadow. The three shadows are inscribed (from top down): "umbre engreant / umbre omn? / umbre angrossissant"

decoNote.title: The sun, phases of the moon, and the shadow of the earth
decoNote.note: Comment la lune rechoipt diversement sa clarte et lumiere poeut chascun veour y chi
Two diagrams each shows a pair of suns labeled "Sol," a small grey earth labeled "terra" and two black bands labeled "luna"

decoNote.title: Lunar eclipse
decoNote.note: Comment les eclipses de la lune adviennent
Label "Sol" in the margin outside the diagram; "Luna" and "Ter/ra" are written to the left of the representation of the eclipse

decoNote.title: Solar eclipse
decoNote.note: Upper gray orb labeled "Terre," smaller silver moon below on black band labeled "Umbre engrellant"

decoNote.title: Solar eclipse at the time of the Crucifixion
decoNote.note: Del eclipse qui advint a la mort de nostre seigneur

decoNote.title: Spheres of the firmament, Christ enthroned, and Evangelist symbols
decoNote.note: Concentric spheres of the universe labeled from the center to the top: "Terre," "Yaue," "Air," "Feus," "Luna," "Mercurius," "Venus," "Sol," "Mars," "Jupiter," "Saturnus," "Firmamentum," "Celum nonu[m]," "Celum cristallinum," "Celum imperium"; names of the Evangelists are inscribed on the scrolls held by the symbols

binding.p: Bound in Paris by León Gruel in the late nineteenth-early twentieth century with red morocco. Foliate motifs in blind on sides and spine. On the spine in blind: "Le miroire / Du Monde" "M.S. 1489" at tail-edge above binder's name "GRUEL"; crimson silk ribbon marker.

history.provenance: Made in Bruges, dated "14.89. 20. februarii" in colophon on fol. 134r
Léon Gruel and Edmond Engelmann collection, Paris, late nineteenth to early twentieth century; their bookplate on inside upper board, inscribed "No. 76"
Henry Walters, Baltimore, acquired from Gruel between 1900 and 1931
history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters' bequest
